turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: We will hear arguments next in 75-823, Belcher v. Stengel.
We will be ready in the moment to counsel.
Mr. Bell, you may proceed whenever you are ready.

turn.speaker: robert_a_bell
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Bell
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court.
This case is here up on the writ of certiorari the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit.

On the question to the fact that an off-duty police officer, out of uniform, is required by Police Department Regulation to carry a weapon at all times, establish that any use of that weapon against the person of another, even though the officer is engaged in private conduct, at the time to be an action ‘under color of law’ within the meeting of 42 U.S.C Section 1983.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Sometime at your own convenience, fit it in wherever you wish, I would like to have you explain to me why the conduct that’s reflected by this record of this officer is any different from what it have been, had he been specifically detailed to work overtime that he has worked beyond his ordinary workday or workweek, if you will deal with that problem at some point?

turn.speaker: robert_a_bell
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Bell
turn.text: I can deal with it in just a moment, Mr. Chief Justice.
The officer testified that he was a uniformed officer on foot patrol in area in Columbus, Ohio that is known as one of the most difficult areas to patrol.
The facts of this case will bear out that he was off-duty out of uniform and was a Columbus police officer.
So, had he been on overtime, I would respectfully suggest he would have been in uniform.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, the uniformed officer might be detailed overtime work in plain clothes that’s not uncommon thing to do?

turn.speaker: robert_a_bell
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Bell
turn.text: No, Your Honor, it is not a common thing but again it would depend, I think depending upon other factors and that this officer was a foot officer on patrol.
Normally, they would not be assigned to plain clothes duty, doing overtime and I am not to say that, that’s true in every case.
On March 1st 1971, the petitioner, off-duty, out of uniform, and was a member of the Columbus Police Department, a Columbus police officer.
Approximately at 1:15 AM in the morning, was in a public bar known as Jimmy's Cafe in Columbus, Ohio on the private, social activity.
An altercation developed in this bar between Respondents and other persons in the bar, not including the Petitioner at this time.
The Petitioner then became involved in this altercation and as a result of his becoming involved in this altercation, he resorted to the use of a 32 Caliber automatic weapon.
Firing it into the air and the use of this weapon resulted in the deaths of Respondents, decedents know and injuries to the Respondent, Stengel.
The Respondents then filed two complaints on the state of facts briefly stated.
Filed a complaint in the Court of Common Pleas Franklin County, Ohio, State Court and a complaint in United States District Court alleging violation of 14 or 42 U.S.C 1983.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Does Ohio have a tort claims act that permits suit against municipal corporations or the State?

turn.speaker: robert_a_bell
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Bell
turn.text: No sir, to answer your question.
The complaint…

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That is still sovereign immunity in most areas in Ohio, is that correct?

turn.speaker: robert_a_bell
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Bell
turn.text: It’s correct, Justice Stevens.
The Respondents dismissed their complaints…

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Specifically, is Columbus an area where the doctrine of sovereign immunity applies?

turn.speaker: robert_a_bell
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Bell
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Either against the municipality or what would be the municipality?

turn.speaker: robert_a_bell
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Bell
turn.text: Municipality, not against the officers, but against municipality.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Against municipality, I mean the municipality would be exempt from liability by the doctrine of sovereign immunity under high laws, is that correct?

turn.speaker: robert_a_bell
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Bell
turn.text: Correct and in the Federal System and Monroe versus Pape, the City of Columbus is not a person under 1983.

Now, the complaint was dismissed in the State Court by Respondents and he proceeded to try the case in United States District Court upon the complaint they filed stating and joining 12 officers along with the Respondent, Belcher.
At the close of the plaintiff’s case that the 12 officers were dismissed and the Respondent remained in the case.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What was the theory on which the other 12 officers were originally joined?

turn.speaker: robert_a_bell
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Bell
turn.text: Under 1985, Title 42 conspiracies to one, to cover up the acts of the Respondent Belcher and two, to deprive the Respondents of the constitutional rights under 42 U.S.C. 1985.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Were they in effect Belcher’s superiors?

turn.speaker: robert_a_bell
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Bell
turn.text: That is correct, and they were in the chain of command.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Bell, also was there not an enquiry by the Police Court of Enquiry?

turn.speaker: robert_a_bell
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Bell
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Is that initiated by the Respondent or how did that come about?

turn.speaker: robert_a_bell
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Bell
turn.text: Well, in the Board of Enquiry, which was the Firearms Board, which meets every time an officer uses his firearm, was initiated automatically under the regulations of the Columbus Police Department.
It was not initiated by the Respondents.

The complaint alleged facts in general in the paragraphs 4 and 5, making general allegations and as we say conclusions of law that at all times, defendants acted ‘under color of law’ and in line of duty.
But in alleging the facts as to the Petitioner’s conduct in paragraph 8 of the complaint.
The allegations accepted is true and thinking in their best like for the plaintiff can only leave the conclusion that the Petitioner did not act ‘under color of law’.
The facts alleged in paragraph 8 of the complaint, if I may briefly refer to them.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I didn’t see complaint in the appendix, is it?

turn.speaker: robert_a_bell
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Bell
turn.text: Yes Your Honor and it’s began at page 8, volume one and I am referring to page 10 of the…

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I see that two volumes…

turn.speaker: robert_a_bell
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Bell
turn.text: Correct.
Volume one, page 10…

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I see…

turn.speaker: robert_a_bell
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Bell
turn.text: And I am reading at the bottom where notice that says, paragraph 8, I am reading at the bottom where it begins, “Raymond L. Belcher, who was out of uniform and in no way identified as a Columbus policeman and in no way involved in the minor dispute heretofore describe intervened by attacking one of the plaintiffs at the scene from the rear by grabbing him around the neck from the rear.

Said intervention by said Raymond L. Belcher 8.33 being without any notification or attempt to notify anybody in the café that he was an off-duty Columbus policeman and without any attempt by said Raymond L. Belcher to make the police arrest, or a citizen’s arrest of any kind at this time.

The facts go on to state, Casey B. Stengel, one of the respondents, before the Court, attempted to kick the chemical mace equipment, which Raymond L. Belcher pulled from his clothing and which was blinding and choking the people involved from the hand of the said Raymond L. Belcher.

Whereupon, still without any warning, identification, or attempt to make an arrest, said Raymond L. Belcher pulled a gun from his clothing, which gun he was ordered and directed to carry as an off-duty Columbus policeman and that time he shot into the air resulting in the deaths of the Respondent Noel, Respondent Ruff (ph) and injury to Respondent Stengel.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What do you mean shot into to the air?

turn.speaker: robert_a_bell
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Bell
turn.text: That was the testimony of Raymond L. Belcher.
He was testified that he was on the floor on his back being stumped and at that time, he pulled the gun out from under his back and shot into the air to get these men off to him.
The shots struck and caused the damage.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That man over on top of him?

turn.speaker: robert_a_bell
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Bell
turn.text: Yes, Mr. Justice.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Has there been some change in position by both you and your adversary in this case, Mr. Bell, I gathered from what the allegations you have read in the complaint that the suggestion that the police officer did not ever assert who he was and that he never made any attempt to make an arrest.

10.34 the further the plaintiff’s cause and on the other hand, I gather from other material on the record that 10.42 whoever defended the case for Mr. Belcher defended it on the basis that he was more less acting in the line of duty.

turn.speaker: robert_a_bell
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Bell
turn.text: That is correct.

That was a statement made at the close by the Defense Counsel and then the City Attorney, who prior to that and at the time of this act, was the Saftey Director and issued an order and a letter to Mr. Belcher.
The statement was made at the conclusion of the plaintiff’s case and argument for a directed verdict of acquittal.
The Court did not accept that statement as I understand it as a stipulation because he went on further to charge the jury as to the facts.
I submit…

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Using this clause and arguments too?

turn.speaker: robert_a_bell
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Bell
turn.text: Yes, he did and I respectfully submit.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And you really emphasized it?

turn.speaker: robert_a_bell
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Bell
turn.text: Mr. Justice that the statement at the including argument was not evidence and I respectfully submit that the statement at the conclusion of the plaintiff’s case was not evidenced.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Bell, there was evidence; the Police Enquiry Board found precisely the same thing and that was evidence, wasn’t that?

turn.speaker: robert_a_bell
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Bell
turn.text: The Police Enquiry Board did find that the officer has justified in use of his weapon…

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And was acting in the line of duty.

turn.speaker: robert_a_bell
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Bell
turn.text: …In the line of duty.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And was that evidence put into the record by the plaintiff for the defendant?

turn.speaker: robert_a_bell
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Bell
turn.text: Well, I was not at the trial and I don’t recall, I am sure it was put in by the defendant or I mean, by the plaintiff.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, you supported the argument Defense Counsel made it because of the plaintiff’s case and it closed the entire case would it?
Wouldn’t you put that evidence in?

turn.speaker: robert_a_bell
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Bell
turn.text: Could have.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Certainly, would have been consistent with this theory of defense anyway.

turn.speaker: robert_a_bell
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Bell
turn.text: It would have been consistent with his theory of defense, but I can’t answer you as to the Defense Counsel but I am sure that the plaintiff would put that into.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You say there is no evidence with that, your statement in the closing argument by the City of (Inaudible) Bonnie Lawman related for you a conversation that she heard at the bar, between these three people in which one of them said, “He is the cop”, is that accurate statement?

turn.speaker: robert_a_bell
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Bell
turn.text: The statement from Bonnie Lawman was the only statement that we could find that it indicated.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I thought that man you got was no evidence.
This mean there wasn’t much?

turn.speaker: robert_a_bell
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Bell
turn.text: Well, Mr. Justice Marshall, the statements by Bonnie Lawman was, as far as we were concerned, was what she heard, number one, and we know from the testimony of the Petitioner that he did not identify himself or attempt to act ‘under color of law’ even though the Respondents may have thought he was or even questioned him.
They did not perceive his actions from as I see -- read the paragraph 8 of the complaint where I am arguing at this point to have been acting ‘under color of law’.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: In your view of the Federal Statute and this complaint, if Belcher had been in uniform and on-duty at that time and place, what would be the situation under the Federal Statute?

turn.speaker: robert_a_bell
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Bell
turn.text: If he had been in uniform and on-duty, he had been acting under code of law.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What was that?

turn.speaker: robert_a_bell
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Bell
turn.text: Because he would have to 14.12 the authority, he would have the 14.14, symbol of it.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Let’s assume all that with the plaintiff, that you can see that the plaintiff would then have had a valid action under the Civil Rights Statute?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Or would you only have a valid action if you can show excessive force beyond anything necessary?

turn.speaker: robert_a_bell
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Bell
turn.text: That’s what I was going to lead up to.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, then why would he then?

turn.speaker: robert_a_bell
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Bell
turn.text: Well, because if excessive force is used ‘under color of law’ that is the very thing that 1983 seeks to protect.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, why did -- does 1983 talk about the deprivation of rights secured by the federal constitution or law?

turn.speaker: robert_a_bell
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Bell
turn.text: In the Fourteenth Amendment.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Why is that a violation of Fourteenth Amendment?

turn.speaker: robert_a_bell
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Bell
turn.text: The taking of life, the Fourteenth Amendment…

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: No, the Fourteenth Amendment does not forbid the taking of life.

turn.speaker: robert_a_bell
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Bell
turn.text: Well, perhaps, Mr. Justice, I don’t understand your question.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, my question is pretty basic one in this case.

It’s one that wasn’t even discussed, it was hardly discussed by either District Court and the Court of Appeals, but why even assuming that this was -- let’s assume that this policeman, Mr. Belcher, was in uniform and on-duty, and let's further assume that everything happened the way it did happen, why were the victims of his shooting where 15.41 one person was injured very seriously and two were killed as I understand it.
Why would they have an action under 1983?

turn.speaker: robert_a_bell
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Bell
turn.text: Because under 1983 if there is an abuse of authority or a misuse of authority, as stated in the traditional cases that have been before this Court before.
That is a violation of the constitutional right.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Of what constitutional right?

turn.speaker: robert_a_bell
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Bell
turn.text: The right to not be punished without due process of law.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, that involves the judicial system. At least, it’s always been thought to.
We have a case that’s going to be argued and I guess later today, 16.23 but generally traditionally that involved the judicial system and the penal system, isn’t it?

turn.speaker: robert_a_bell
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Bell
turn.text: Yes, but in the traditional case, the cases before this Court, the law has been set forth that the misuse of power possessed by virtue of State law and made possible only because the wrong door is closed with the authority of State law, is action taken under color of law, State law 16.49.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Alright, but let’s assume this is all taken under color of law, I have assumed that.

turn.speaker: robert_a_bell
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Bell
turn.text: Alright, therefore, if he takes action under color of law and misuse that authority to, let’s say…

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You remember, you are representing Mr. Belcher, you are not on the other side?

turn.speaker: robert_a_bell
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Bell
turn.text: I realize that, I realize that, but I am trying to be professionally honest with the Court as I can.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Yes, I understand that but I really don’t -- let’s assume that policeman in uniform, on-duty but not in an emergency; he is just driving from one station house to another, drives with gross and one negligence and strikes and kills somebody, does he has deprived that victim of his gross and improper behavior of any constitutional right?

turn.speaker: robert_a_bell
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Bell
turn.text: It is our position and he would not in that case.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, then what’s a difference between in that case and this case?

turn.speaker: robert_a_bell
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Bell
turn.text: There is no difference in that sense, but in our position of that case and this case, as you stated and that is what I am arguing.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, no, no, because in each case, he is acting under color of law.

Now, your present case I know that you argue that he would isn’t, right, but I am assuming that he is in both cases, both in the bar in Columbus, Ohio and hypothetically, in uniform and on-duty and also on the street in Columbus, Ohio where he just weaves and speeds and there is no emergency and he kills somebody.
Now, why an either case, is the victim deprived of any right guaranteed by the federal constitution or federal law?

turn.speaker: robert_a_bell
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Bell
turn.text: Right, in the latter case, Mr. Justice Stewart, I agree that the victim of the automobile would not be deprived of constitutional right and would not be in action under 1983.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What about an officer in uniform approaches a bank and a bank robbery is going and he engages in a gunfight with the bank robbers, but inadvertently shoots and kills one of the customers or one of the employees of the bank.
Do you think that’s covered by 1983?

turn.speaker: robert_a_bell
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Bell
turn.text: No, Your Honor, we do not and that is the one of the reason of our argument, that’s one of the purposes of our argument that we do not feel that 1983 should 19.02 under the color law should be extended to include these private acts and they would open up…

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Within the theory of your case -- then the theory of your case might more appropriately either this man was, in fact, on-duty and engaged in the normal functioning of the police under the special instructions to carry gun at all times.

turn.speaker: robert_a_bell
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Bell
turn.text: It is our contention that the District Court hits on that spirit that he was carrying the gun only in his charge and we feel that overall that charge is not objected, to which I will get to later in argument, we feel that it was fundamental error.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Bell, let me get back I mean if you answer to Justice Stewart’s question.
You said that in the squad car incident which Justice Stewart hypothesized, you felt that was not a violation of any constitutional right.

turn.speaker: robert_a_bell
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Bell
turn.text: Correct.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: The information was that you failed in the bar case it is a violation of constitutional right?

turn.speaker: robert_a_bell
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Bell
turn.text: It could be.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What would you turn on?

turn.speaker: robert_a_bell
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Bell
turn.text: I would turn on my judgment, it would turn on if the officer arrested the person, took him into custody and then proceeded to be the confession out of him or to in someway…

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That would be like Screws?

turn.speaker: robert_a_bell
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Bell
turn.text: Screws, yes, Your Honor, or the…

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What Screws said he had to do with an intent and expressed intent that denied any right guaranteed by the constitution.

turn.speaker: robert_a_bell
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Bell
turn.text: That is correct and this Court reversed the Screws’ case upon the charge of the Court, calling it fundamental error because the Court did not charge on that very point, Justice Marshall, and that was a criminal case under 18 U.S.C Section 242.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But the constitutional rights 20.54 of a State is precisely the same, there wasn’t the right to…

turn.speaker: robert_a_bell
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Bell
turn.text: Excuse me, sir.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: The constitutional right of the State in Screws is precisely the same, the right not to be deprived of life without due process of law.

turn.speaker: robert_a_bell
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Bell
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Yeah.

turn.speaker: robert_a_bell
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Bell
turn.text: To further answer Justice Rehnquist’s question, the case most in point is the matter of Williams v. The U.S. where a Private Detective in State of Florida was engaged by a lumberyard to catch petty thieves and he had an authorization issued from the State.
He also had within an on-duty police officer in uniform.

He would catch these people, take them to a pain shed and plead confessions out of them, literally, beat confessions out of them and at the time that he was doing it, which is very significant I suggest, he was flashing his batch, his color of authority.
This was not done in this case.

Now, we respectfully submit that the facts in this complaint indicate private conduct in that it lacks the jurisdictional -- creates a jurisdictional fault in the District Court, as attempting to include within 1983 those matters that are private acts that we have just discussed.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Right, you started I think at the outset of your statement of the case, Mr. Bell, by telling us that a companion suit had been filed in the Franklin County Court of Common Pleas.

turn.speaker: robert_a_bell
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Bell
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Then what happened to that suit?

turn.speaker: robert_a_bell
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Bell
turn.text: That was dismissed by Respondents and they elected to…

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Dismissed by the plaintiffs?

turn.speaker: robert_a_bell
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Bell
turn.text: Yes.

Therefore, the only fact in the complaint from which we can derive official conduct of the Court police is the use of the weapon, which complaint alleges petitioner carrying pursuant to a department regulation requiring off-duty officers to carry a weapon at all reasonable times, under a theory that officers are on-duty 24 hours per day.
To focus upon the use of that weapon alone, coupled with the facts stated leading to the conclusion that they will use in only in a totally private manner.

We feel it does not state facts upon relief can be granted and as if the weapon used is by and of itself determine to satisfy the under color of law requirement, then once again, the traditionally excluded private uses that we have already discussed with the Court.
We will be -- within the ambit of 42 U.S.C. 1983.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Bell, you say just the use of the private weapon, but does the record tell us why the defendant became involved in the incident?
His motivation, was it a private motivation or an effort to maintain the peace?

turn.speaker: robert_a_bell
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Bell
turn.text: There was a conflict of testimony on this point.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: If we take these evidence most favorably to the verdict, do we not have to assume that he thought to bright about peace and therefore perform his duties as an officer?

turn.speaker: robert_a_bell
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Bell
turn.text: It is our position that whether he sought -- either that interpretation or if he became an aggressor or is it a matter of self-defense, it doesn’t matter, because he did not attempt to act under color of law as it’s been defined by the cases in this Court.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What is your theory of what he was trying to do when he got involved?

turn.speaker: robert_a_bell
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Bell
turn.text: The evidence was that he was sitting in the booth with a lady friend and two other people.
The altercation that the fired into bar among Respondents...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Between the plaintiffs and third party?

turn.speaker: robert_a_bell
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Bell
turn.text: Third parties.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And why did he get involved?

turn.speaker: robert_a_bell
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Bell
turn.text: Alright.

First, the testimony was that he said, well, I am going to arrest three, no I am going to arrest two of the officers that’s part of it in the evidence and then he said, I am going to go to the phone and call on-duty officers, and he never got…
Excuse me, sir.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: It is not true that both of those statements are inconsistent with the purely private motivation and do they not add to the evidence of the gun, so can you properly say there is nothing with the gun involved in the case?

turn.speaker: robert_a_bell
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Bell
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, it is our position that the matter of fact that he sought to get out the bar to get to a phone, was not an act under color of law that would bring the Respondents -- they would perceive that they were acting under the color of law and that they were going to be arrested or that the petitioner was an officer.
The act alone, to trying to get out of the bar to get to the phone, does not make him the police officer.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Wouldn’t that act alone have done the most sensible thing to do if he had been in uniform, on-duty to call for some backup help?

turn.speaker: robert_a_bell
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Bell
turn.text: I think he would have, I think yes, sir.
I agree with that.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, then that’s consistent with what your response was to Justice Stevens which adds up to me that he was engaged in police activity.
